channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #213 - YAPC::EU is just a week from now
item.description:
Hi there

I have not been to YAPC::EU since Frankfurt 2012 that was after the attempt to bring Perl 5 and Perl 6 closer together which took place in Perl, Germany.

What happened since then? Have people got closer?

Will the official release of Perl 6 bring new people to the "Perl community"? Who cares?

I am looking forward to see what others say about this.

In the meantime, enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: File::Slurp is broken and wrong
item.description: Instead of that module Leon suggests File::Slurper, Path::Tiny, or even IO::All. I personally think that this whole thing, including the discussion on Reddit indicate serious problems in the Perl culture. How many people will see this post? How will all the others know what is the recommended way to slurp a file into memory?

item.title: Turn capture groups into cluster groups
item.description: Instead of using (?:...) many times, you can just use the /n flag and turn every capture group into a cluster group. Or, you can use (?n...) to turn off capturing in part of the regex. Of course there are a lot more details in the article.

item.title: Perl 5 Regex Cheat sheet
item.description: Quick look-up for the major regex features of Perl 5 with links to detailed explanation and examples.

item.title: I Need To Write This Up To Understand It, or The Epic Battle between Wat and Derp!
Playing with the TrueRNG 2 hardware random number generator
item.description: Even if you write your code in C, you can still include a Perl script

item.title: Writing DuckDuckGo plugins just got easier
Perl on the Rebound?
item.description: Just linking to two interesting articles: From the languages which I've used, only Perl has tried to address the problem. and We're Still Catching Up to Perl. Read those if you'd like to warm your heart.

item.title: Our Latest Sponsor: ABC Startsiden
item.description: ABC Startsiden is sponsoring the CPAN Testers.

item.title: swat for Dancer
item.description: SWAT is simple DSL to create a smoke tests for any web application in easy and fast way. Dancer is a modern light-weight web framework for Perl

item.title: Preparing for a Technical Interview (with Perl)
item.description: Slides, apparently from YAPC::NA that might help you get your next job.

item.title: Getting big without getting fat, in perl
item.description: How to grow an ad-hoc script turned into enterprise software without creating a monster? Use the 4 elements of the programmers culture: Config, Logging, Testing, Plugins.

item.title: Want to help?
item.description: The Perl NOC is looking for help cleaning up inactive Perl Monger groups, improving the spam filters and moving services to Docker.

item.title: DMARC and Mailing Lists
Perl 6 Hague Grant Application
Reading Excel file using Perl
item.description: Using Spreadsheet::ParseExcel::Simple and Spreadsheet::ParseExcel, but actually recommending Spreadsheet::Read

item.title: I Am Unlikely To Move To Perl6
item.description: The imminent official release of Perl 6 brings up even more emotions. Dave describes his background and rationally explains his emotions toward Perl 6.

item.title: Sites with public API with CORS - Cross-Origin Resource Sharing enabled

item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;

item.title: Q&A Session with Larry Wall at Swiss Perl Workshop 2015
item.description: The Swiss Perl Workshop is just around the corner. Can you make it there?

item.title: YAPC::EU
item.description: Right after the Swiss Perl Workshop you can come to Granada, Spain for European Perl Conference.

item.title: Just announced: PPW talk deadline extended!
item.description: Further down the road there is the Pittsburgh Perl Workshop, the only Perl Workshop promoted by The Perl Foundation, waiting for more talk proposals.
